awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Mass Shootings and the Gun Control and Gun Rights Movements
awd_abstract_narration:
Mass Shootings and the Gun Control and Gun Rights Movements
PI: David S. Meyer
Co-PI: Eulalie Laschever

This study examines how the gun control and gun rights movements responded to the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School on December 14, 2012, and the policy impact of their efforts. The research will also attempt to explain why 29 states relaxed firearms restrictions, while 16 states tightened restrictions in the two years that followed the shooting. This study employs two methods of analysis. First, to determine how the gun control and gun rights movements responded to the event, the Co-PI compares two different  cases to assess how and if two major national gun control organizations and two major national gun rights organizations changed their policy agendas, targets,tactics, and organizational structures between 2011 and 2014. Second, the co-PI uses qualitative comparative analysis to show why some states strengthened firearms restrictions while others relaxed restrictions during the 2011-2012 and the 2013-2014 legislative sessions. The findings of this study will be useful to scholars who study social movements, public health, state-level policy change, and professional political organizations. In addition, this study will contribute to public knowledge and discourse about social movements in America.

This dissertation contributes to the academic literatures on social movement strategy and on policy outcomes by explaining how movement organizations respond to critical events and why laws sometimes change during the political debate that follows them. There is agreement in the literature that critical events are important for social movements. Little is known, however, about how opposing movement organizations change in response to such events, or how these responses are mediated by other features of the political context and by each organization?s own internal constraints. Similarly, scholars have established that critical events can shake up the political agenda and facilitate policy change. But we still know little about the conditions that facilitate policy change after such events, or whether these conditions are distinct from those that fostered similar policy changes before the event occurred. The Co-PI will conduct intensive case studies of two important gun control organizations and two important gun rights organizations about their organizational structures, targets, tactics, and political agendas between 2011 and 2014. To answer the second question, she will conduct fuzzy-set qualitative comparative analysis (fsQCA) to determine what factors led to changes in state-level firearms restrictions in the legislative sessions before and after the shooting. The researcher will compare the conditions that led to four different state-level policy outcomes.  This dissertation has two objectives: 1) to detail how political organizations respond to critical events; and 2) to determine the conditions under which state laws change after such events. The findings of this study will be useful to scholars who study social movements, public health, state-level policy change, and professional political organizations. This study will also contribute to public knowledge and discourse in America.

por.por_cntn:
Events that generate high levels of media, public, and political attention, and that shift public opinion, present an opportunity for social movements to mobilize support for their goals and to secure policy change. Because the raw attention an event generates fades quickly in the crowded public agenda, many shocking events have no lasting impact. Even after this attention fades, though, movement actors can keep using the event to mobilize support for their goals. Therefore, it is how activists use the event that will determine whether the event has an impact. A political organization's ability to secure policy change after such an event depends on how it navigates the political venues that are available to it, whether it deploys its resources effectively, and whether its opponents are able to block it. 

The research supported by this award was designed to show how two key gun control organizations (the Brady Campaign to Prevent Gun Violence and Everytown for Gun Safety) and two key gun rights organizations (the National Rifle Association and the Second Amendment Foundation) respond to the shooting at Sandy Hook Elementary School in December 2012, and determine the conditions under which each side secured desired state-level policy change. To determine how the gun control movement maximized policy gains and gun rights movement minimized policy losses, this project used historical-comparative and ethnographic techniques to compile and analyze over 100 hours of fieldwork, thousands of organizational documents and newspaper articles, and informal interviews related to these four organizations.

The results of this project show that gun control groups first responded to the opportunity that the shooting presented shifting to an aggressively offensive stance and by channeling their attention into pressuring Congress to enact new gun control legislation. When these efforts failed, they redirected and diversified their efforts, focusing instead on advancing their agenda in the states, through state legislatures, the courts, electoral referendums, and local movement-building efforts. By contrast, gun rights groups initially responded by assuming a far more defensive stance and focusing their attention on using the threat of gun control to mobilize their supporters and build their national movement. They devoted relatively little attention to blocking the gun control movement’s efforts to secure national legislation, and instead split their attention between advancing their own state-level legislative goals and defending against those of their opponents. When gun control groups took their fight to the states, gun rights groups used this threat to focus their attention on building up the gun rights movement at the state level.

While Congress passed no national gun laws after Sandy Hook, states passed 113 laws in 2013 that either tightened, relaxed, or amended firearms restrictions. They passed an additional 125 laws in 2014. The number gun laws that states passed in 2013 and 2014 is especially striking considering that states only passed 78 laws in 2011 and only 44 in 2012. This suggests that in a gridlocked national political climate, states represent the crucial arena for understanding opposing movement mobilization and influence after a critical event like the Sandy Hook Shooting. This project demonstrates that the gun control movement and gun rights movement both secured more policy change after the shooting. But while the gun rights movement secured far more policy change than the gun control movement in the legislative session before the shooting, after the shooting the gun control movement overcame this disadvantage by securing far bigger legislative victories. This outcome, however, hinged on these states receiving attention from these national gun control organizations.
